verses.text: Elihu continued, and said:
verses.comment: Elihu, the youngest of Job's friends, continues his speech. He claims to bring further insight, showing youthful confidence and a claim to divinely inspired wisdom. Elihu stands as a mediator who foreshadows the idea of instruction by those raised up by God.

verses.text: "Bear with me a little while, and I will show you; for I have more words to speak on God's behalf.
verses.comment: Elihu emphasizes patience from his audience, as he believes his words carry divine authority. This recalls the need to give ear to those who speak for God, anticipating the New Testament office of teaching (cf. 1 Tim. 3:15 - the 'pillar and foundation of truth').

verses.text: I will get my knowledge from afar, and ascribe righteousness to my Maker.
verses.comment: Elihu draws from God's wisdom, not human speculation, and affirms God's righteousness. This points to the transcendence of divine wisdom, as later affirmed by Paul (1 Cor. 1:25).

verses.text: For truly, my words are not false; one who is perfect in knowledge is with you.
verses.comment: Elihu claims integrity and intimate knowledge of God, which foreshadows the New Testament's emphasis on truth-speaking elders and the authority of those charged with instruction (Titus 1:9).

verses.text: Behold, God is mighty, but does not despise anyone; He is mighty in strength of understanding.
verses.comment: Elihu highlights both God's power and His care for individuals, reflecting the divine reality that true strength does not negate compassion—a principle embodied in Christ.

verses.text: He does not keep the wicked alive, but gives justice to the afflicted.
verses.comment: God's justice ensures both judgment for the wicked and mercy for the lowly. This echoes the justice found in Christ’s ministry—where the humble are lifted up (Luke 1:52).

verses.text: He does not withdraw His eyes from the righteous, but with kings on the throne He sets them forever, and they are exalted.
verses.comment: God watches over the righteous and exalts them. This mirrors the New Testament teaching that the humble will be exalted (Luke 14:11). There are echoes here of the enduring nature of God’s kingdom and the upholding of His chosen leaders.

verses.text: But if they are bound in chains, caught in cords of affliction,
verses.comment: Suffering is sometimes a means for the righteous to be drawn to God. The motif of discipline as purifying anticipates the idea of redemptive suffering.

verses.text: then He declares to them their deeds and their transgressions, that they have acted arrogantly.
verses.comment: God uses suffering to reveal sin and urge repentance, a theme found throughout Scripture and in Christian practice, especially in the sacramental life of confession and repentance.

verses.text: He opens their ears to instruction, and commands them to turn from evil.
verses.comment: Here, God initiates correction, highlighting the necessity of listening and responding—a foundation for true conversion. This listening parallels faith coming by hearing, emphasized later in Romans 10:17.

verses.text: If they listen and serve Him, they will complete their days in prosperity, and their years in pleasures.
verses.comment: Obedience brings reward, a principle both for present blessing and, spiritually, eternal life. Parallels are drawn with Jesus' teaching on the reward for those who keep the commands (Matt. 19:17).

verses.text: But if they do not listen, they will perish by the sword and die without knowledge.
verses.comment: Rejection of God's instruction leads to destruction. This is consistent with Jesus’ repeated warnings to those who harden their hearts (Luke 13:3).

verses.text: The godless in heart harbor anger; they do not cry for help when He binds them.
verses.comment: Unrepentant hearts fail to turn to God, showing the danger of pride and self-reliance. The fruit of humility is often the gift of supplication.

verses.text: They die in their youth, and their life ends among the unclean.
verses.comment: Refusal to repent leads to an untimely and dishonorable end, reminiscent of warnings about the fate of the unrepentant found both in Psalms and the teachings of Christ.

verses.text: He delivers the afflicted by their affliction, and opens their ear in oppression.
verses.comment: Affliction as a means of deliverance anticipates the redemptive value of suffering, which is fulfilled in the passion of Christ (Heb. 2:10), and in the path of sanctification through trial.

verses.text: He also lures you out of distress into a broad place, where there is no narrowness, and your table is loaded with fatness.
verses.comment: God’s redemption leads from suffering to abundance, a theme central both to Israel’s exodus and fulfilled by Christ who prepares the heavenly banquet.

verses.text: But you are filled with the judgment due to the wicked; judgment and justice seize you.
verses.comment: Job’s sense of resentment brings him close to the consequence reserved for the wicked, showing the need for trust in God’s ultimate justice.

verses.text: Beware that wrath does not entice you into scoffing, and do not let the greatness of the ransom turn you aside.
verses.comment: Warning against despair or scorn in affliction. The mention of ransom subtly alludes to the notion of atonement and the price paid for redemption.

verses.text: Will your cry for help avail you, or even all your strength, so that you are not in distress?
verses.comment: Human effort or pleading alone does not save—divine grace is necessary, a key to salvation taught throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Do not long for the night, when peoples vanish in their place.
verses.comment: The night alludes to death or destruction; longing for escape outside God’s will is discouraged. True hope lies in God’s timing and providence.

verses.text: Take care; do not turn to iniquity, for you have chosen this rather than affliction.
verses.comment: Affliction must not become the ground for sin. Enduring suffering faithfully is a theme picked up powerfully in Christ’s own passion.

verses.text: Behold, God is exalted in His power; who is a teacher like Him?
verses.comment: God as the ultimate teacher points forward to Christ, who is called ‘Rabbi’ and whose instruction surpasses all others.

verses.text: Who has assigned Him His way, or who can say, 'You have done wrong'?
verses.comment: No one can correct God. This humility before God is echoed by Paul’s argument on God’s sovereignty.

verses.text: "Remember to exalt His work, of which people have sung.
verses.comment: Praise and worship is the right response to God's works—a theme central to all sacred liturgy where God is exalted communally.

verses.text: All people have looked on it; everyone beholds it from afar.
verses.comment: God’s glory in creation is evident to all, as Paul later wrote about the manifestation of God’s attributes in nature (Rom. 1:20).

verses.text: Behold, God is great, and we do not know Him; the number of His years is unsearchable.
verses.comment: God’s transcendence and mystery remain even as He reveals Himself in creation—a mystery entering fully into revelation through Christ. God’s eternity is emphasized here.

verses.text: For He draws up the drops of water; they distill His mist in rain,
verses.comment: God’s providence is seen in the operation of nature, especially the cycle of water—a picture of His continual care for creation.

verses.text: which the skies pour down and drop upon man abundantly.
verses.comment: Rain is a symbol of God’s blessing given to all people, connecting to Jesus' teaching of God's impartial generosity (Matt. 5:45).

verses.text: Can anyone understand the spreading of the clouds, the thunderings of His pavilion?
verses.comment: God’s might is often illustrated through natural phenomena whose causes remain beyond full human comprehension.

verses.text: Behold, He spreads His light around Him and covers the depths of the sea.
verses.comment: God’s dominion over light and the sea displays His sovereignty—themes developed by Christ’s calming of the sea and declaration 'I am the light of the world.'

verses.text: For by these He judges peoples; He gives food in abundance.
verses.comment: Natural phenomena are instruments both of judgment and of provision. This abundance fulfills a dual purpose, foreshadowed sacramentally in God’s provision for His people.

verses.text: He covers His hands with lightning and commands it to strike the mark.
verses.comment: The image of God wielding lightning evokes awe and power, reinforcing that nothing happens outside His command.

verses.text: Its thunder tells of His presence, the cattle also declare the storm is coming.
verses.comment: Even nature proclaims God’s approach—in thunder, in animal instincts—affirming that creation testifies to the Creator’s power and authority.
